title: How to Fix a Stripped Screw Hole

methods.name: Doing a Quick Fix with Toothpicks

steps.headline: Insert as many toothpicks as you can into the stripped screw hole.
steps.description: Get regular wooden toothpicks from a department store or online. You’ll usually be able to fit 2 or 3 toothpicks into the hole. The toothpicks should fit snugly in the hole.

steps.headline: Squeeze 2-3 drops of wood glue on the ends of the toothpicks.
steps.description: After you apply the glue, spread the glue with your finger or a cotton swab so that the toothpicks are completely covered in glue. You can purchase wood glue online or from a hardware store.

steps.headline: Stick the toothpicks into the hole and snap off the excess.
steps.description: Stick the toothpicks into the hole and lightly tap on the ends with a hammer to push them as deep as they can go into the hole. Then, snap off the exposed ends of the toothpicks or break them off with the hammer. The toothpicks should now run flush with the top of the screw hole.

steps.headline: Let the glue dry for at least 1 hour.
steps.description: The glue will fuse the toothpicks to the inside of the stripped screw hole. The wooden toothpicks will create the resistance that the screw’s threads need to stay securely in the hole. Read the instructions on your wood glue to see if drying times differ with the brand of glue that you purchased.

steps.headline: Re-insert the screw back into the hole.
steps.description: Turn the screw clockwise into the screw hole with a screwdriver or drill. Continue turning the screw until the top of the screw runs flush with the hole. The new toothpicks should fill in the spaces in the screw hole and give your screw something to catch on.

steps.headline: Purchase plastic wall plugs online or at a hardware store.
steps.description: Get wall plugs that match the size of your screw. If you’re unsure, use a tape measure or ruler to measure the length of the screw before you purchase the plugs. If you’re buying the plugs at a hardware store, you can bring the screw with you and ask someone for correctly sized plugs.

steps.headline: Bore a new hole equal to the size of the plugs if necessary.
steps.description: If the plugs are too big for the holes, you’ll need to bore new ones so that they can fit. The new holes should be 1–2 centimetres (0.39–0.79 in) longer than the length of your plugs. Then, press the drill against the stripped hole and pull the trigger while pressing down on the drill to bore a new hole. If the wall plugs fit into the existing holes, you don’t need to drill new ones. Hold a plug next to the tip of the drill bit and mark the length with a piece of tape so that you know how deep to drill.

steps.headline: Insert the plug into the hole.
steps.description: If the plug isn’t fitting, tap on the top of the plug with a hammer until it runs flush with the hole. The plug should fit snugly in the hole and should stay in place.

steps.headline: Re-insert the screw into the plastic wall plug.
steps.description: Press the tip of the screw into the plug and use  a screwdriver or drill to screw it back into the hole. The screw will now screw into the threads in the plug.

methods.name: Fixing Large Holes with Automotive Filler

steps.headline: Bore a new hole into the stripped screw hole.
steps.description: Use a drill bit that’s the next size up from the screw. The hole must be bigger than the screw itself so that the automotive filler can fill the hole and cast new threads for your screw. For instance, if you had a ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) screw, you’d bore a hole with a ⁄8 inch (0.95 cm) drill bit. Automotive filler is best used on larger screw holes like ones for bolts and lag screws.

steps.headline: Mix the automotive filler according to the directions.
steps.description: You can purchase automotive filler at an auto body store or online. Read the packaging and instructions that came with the filler first. Then, mix the compounds together on a piece of cardboard with a putty knife to activate the ingredients in the filler. Most automotive filler is made up of 2 putty-like compounds that harden when mixed together.

steps.headline: Fill the hole with the filler.
steps.description: Scoop the filler up with the putty knife and run it over the hole. Completely fill up the hole with the filler before flattening out the top with the putty knife. It may take several scoops until the hole is completely filled.

steps.headline: Spray lubricant onto the end of the screw.
steps.description: The lubricant will help you smoothly remove the screw from the new threads once the automotive filler has hardened. Use a spray-on lubricant like WD-40 to fully saturate the threads on the screw.

steps.headline: Insert the screw into the wet putty.
steps.description: Do not let the filler dry or it will be impossible to insert the screw. Position the screw in the center of the new hole and carefully press down on the top of the screw. The screw will leave an imprint of its threads as it dries. If the filler spills out of the sides, push it back into the holes on the side of the screw with your putty knife.

steps.headline: Let the filler dry for 5 minutes and unscrew the screw.
steps.description: After 5 minutes, carefully turn the screw or bolt counterclockwise to remove it from the filler. When you look down into the hole, you should see new threads formed by the filler. Don’t let the filler fully set or you won’t be able to remove the screw.

steps.headline: Let the automotive filler dry overnight.
steps.description: The filler will set overnight and harden in the shape of the threads on your screw or bolt. This will allow you to secure the screw into the new hole that you created.

text: Doing a Quick Fix with Toothpicks Insert as many toothpicks as you can into the stripped screw hole. Get regular wooden toothpicks from a department store or online. You’ll usually be able to fit 2 or 3 toothpicks into the hole. The toothpicks should fit snugly in the hole. Squeeze 2-3 drops of wood glue on the ends of the toothpicks. After you apply the glue, spread the glue with your finger or a cotton swab so that the toothpicks are completely covered in glue. You can purchase wood glue online or from a hardware store. Stick the toothpicks into the hole and snap off the excess. Stick the toothpicks into the hole and lightly tap on the ends with a hammer to push them as deep as they can go into the hole. Then, snap off the exposed ends of the toothpicks or break them off with the hammer. The toothpicks should now run flush with the top of the screw hole. Let the glue dry for at least 1 hour. The glue will fuse the toothpicks to the inside of the stripped screw hole. The wooden toothpicks will create the resistance that the screw’s threads need to stay securely in the hole. Read the instructions on your wood glue to see if drying times differ with the brand of glue that you purchased. Re-insert the screw back into the hole. Turn the screw clockwise into the screw hole with a screwdriver or drill. Continue turning the screw until the top of the screw runs flush with the hole. The new toothpicks should fill in the spaces in the screw hole and give your screw something to catch on. Using Plastic Wall Plugs Purchase plastic wall plugs online or at a hardware store. Get wall plugs that match the size of your screw. If you’re unsure, use a tape measure or ruler to measure the length of the screw before you purchase the plugs. If you’re buying the plugs at a hardware store, you can bring the screw with you and ask someone for correctly sized plugs. Bore a new hole equal to the size of the plugs if necessary. If the plugs are too big for the holes, you’ll need to bore new ones so that they can fit. The new holes should be 1–2 centimetres (0.39–0.79 in) longer than the length of your plugs. Then, press the drill against the stripped hole and pull the trigger while pressing down on the drill to bore a new hole. If the wall plugs fit into the existing holes, you don’t need to drill new ones. Hold a plug next to the tip of the drill bit and mark the length with a piece of tape so that you know how deep to drill. Insert the plug into the hole. If the plug isn’t fitting, tap on the top of the plug with a hammer until it runs flush with the hole. The plug should fit snugly in the hole and should stay in place. Re-insert the screw into the plastic wall plug. Press the tip of the screw into the plug and use  a screwdriver or drill to screw it back into the hole. The screw will now screw into the threads in the plug. Fixing Large Holes with Automotive Filler Bore a new hole into the stripped screw hole. Use a drill bit that’s the next size up from the screw. The hole must be bigger than the screw itself so that the automotive filler can fill the hole and cast new threads for your screw. For instance, if you had a ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) screw, you’d bore a hole with a ⁄8 inch (0.95 cm) drill bit. Automotive filler is best used on larger screw holes like ones for bolts and lag screws. Mix the automotive filler according to the directions. You can purchase automotive filler at an auto body store or online. Read the packaging and instructions that came with the filler first. Then, mix the compounds together on a piece of cardboard with a putty knife to activate the ingredients in the filler. Most automotive filler is made up of 2 putty-like compounds that harden when mixed together. Fill the hole with the filler. Scoop the filler up with the putty knife and run it over the hole. Completely fill up the hole with the filler before flattening out the top with the putty knife. It may take several scoops until the hole is completely filled. Spray lubricant onto the end of the screw. The lubricant will help you smoothly remove the screw from the new threads once the automotive filler has hardened. Use a spray-on lubricant like WD-40 to fully saturate the threads on the screw. Insert the screw into the wet putty. Do not let the filler dry or it will be impossible to insert the screw. Position the screw in the center of the new hole and carefully press down on the top of the screw. The screw will leave an imprint of its threads as it dries. If the filler spills out of the sides, push it back into the holes on the side of the screw with your putty knife. Let the filler dry for 5 minutes and unscrew the screw. After 5 minutes, carefully turn the screw or bolt counterclockwise to remove it from the filler. When you look down into the hole, you should see new threads formed by the filler. Don’t let the filler fully set or you won’t be able to remove the screw. Let the automotive filler dry overnight. The filler will set overnight and harden in the shape of the threads on your screw or bolt. This will allow you to secure the screw into the new hole that you created.
sentences: Doing a Quick Fix with Toothpicks Insert as many toothpicks as you can into the stripped screw hole.
Get regular wooden toothpicks from a department store or online.
You’ll usually be able to fit 2 or 3 toothpicks into the hole.
The toothpicks should fit snugly in the hole.
Squeeze 2-3 drops of wood glue on the ends of the toothpicks.
After you apply the glue, spread the glue with your finger or a cotton swab so that the toothpicks are completely covered in glue.
You can purchase wood glue online or from a hardware store.
Stick the toothpicks into the hole and snap off the excess.
Stick the toothpicks into the hole and lightly tap on the ends with a hammer to push them as deep as they can go into the hole.
Then, snap off the exposed ends of the toothpicks or break them off with the hammer.
The toothpicks should now run flush with the top of the screw hole.
Let the glue dry for at least 1 hour.
The glue will fuse the toothpicks to the inside of the stripped screw hole.
The wooden toothpicks will create the resistance that the screw’s threads need to stay securely in the hole.
Read the instructions on your wood glue to see if drying times differ with the brand of glue that you purchased.
Re-insert the screw back into the hole.
Turn the screw clockwise into the screw hole with a screwdriver or drill.
Continue turning the screw until the top of the screw runs flush with the hole.
The new toothpicks should fill in the spaces in the screw hole and give your screw something to catch on.
Using Plastic Wall Plugs Purchase plastic wall plugs online or at a hardware store.
Get wall plugs that match the size of your screw.
If you’re unsure, use a tape measure or ruler to measure the length of the screw before you purchase the plugs.
If you’re buying the plugs at a hardware store, you can bring the screw with you and ask someone for correctly sized plugs.
Bore a new hole equal to the size of the plugs if necessary.
If the plugs are too big for the holes, you’ll need to bore new ones so that they can fit.
The new holes should be 1–2 centimetres (0.39–0.79 in) longer than the length of your plugs.
Then, press the drill against the stripped hole and pull the trigger while pressing down on the drill to bore a new hole.
If the wall plugs fit into the existing holes, you don’t need to drill new ones.
Hold a plug next to the tip of the drill bit and mark the length with a piece of tape so that you know how deep to drill.
Insert the plug into the hole.
If the plug isn’t fitting, tap on the top of the plug with a hammer until it runs flush with the hole.
The plug should fit snugly in the hole and should stay in place.
Re-insert the screw into the plastic wall plug.
Press the tip of the screw into the plug and use  a screwdriver or drill to screw it back into the hole.
The screw will now screw into the threads in the plug.
Fixing Large Holes with Automotive Filler Bore a new hole into the stripped screw hole.
Use a drill bit that’s the next size up from the screw.
The hole must be bigger than the screw itself so that the automotive filler can fill the hole and cast new threads for your screw.
For instance, if you had a ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) screw, you’d bore a hole with a ⁄8 inch (0.95 cm) drill bit.
Automotive filler is best used on larger screw holes like ones for bolts and lag screws.
Mix the automotive filler according to the directions.
You can purchase automotive filler at an auto body store or online.
Read the packaging and instructions that came with the filler first.
Then, mix the compounds together on a piece of cardboard with a putty knife to activate the ingredients in the filler.
Most automotive filler is made up of 2 putty-like compounds that harden when mixed together.
Fill the hole with the filler.
Scoop the filler up with the putty knife and run it over the hole.
Completely fill up the hole with the filler before flattening out the top with the putty knife.
It may take several scoops until the hole is completely filled.
Spray lubricant onto the end of the screw.
The lubricant will help you smoothly remove the screw from the new threads once the automotive filler has hardened.
Use a spray-on lubricant like WD-40 to fully saturate the threads on the screw.
Insert the screw into the wet putty.
Do not let the filler dry or it will be impossible to insert the screw.
Position the screw in the center of the new hole and carefully press down on the top of the screw.
The screw will leave an imprint of its threads as it dries.
If the filler spills out of the sides, push it back into the holes on the side of the screw with your putty knife.
Let the filler dry for 5 minutes and unscrew the screw.
After 5 minutes, carefully turn the screw or bolt counterclockwise to remove it from the filler.
When you look down into the hole, you should see new threads formed by the filler.
Don’t let the filler fully set or you won’t be able to remove the screw.
Let the automotive filler dry overnight.
The filler will set overnight and harden in the shape of the threads on your screw or bolt.
This will allow you to secure the screw into the new hole that you created.
